responses.text: Leaves change color in fall because of a green pigment called chlorophyll.
When days get shorter and cooler, trees stop making chlorophyll.
Without the green, other colors like yellow and orange can show through.
Red colors come from sugars trapped in the leaves.
The tree will be fine - it drops leaves to save water for winter.

Chlorophyll.text: Chlorophyll is a green pigment found in plants that absorbs light energy for photosynthesis. It gives leaves their green color during spring and summer.
Chlorophyll.title: Chlorophyll

Autumn_leaf_color.text: Autumn leaf color is a phenomenon that affects the green leaves of many trees, causing them to change color. As daylight decreases in autumn, chlorophyll production slows.
Autumn_leaf_color.title: Autumn leaf color

Carotenoid.text: Carotenoids are yellow, orange, and red pigments present in leaves throughout the year. They become visible when chlorophyll breaks down in autumn.
Carotenoid.title: Carotenoid

Anthocyanin.text: Anthocyanins are red pigments produced in leaves during autumn when sugars become trapped. They create the bright red and purple colors seen in some trees.
Anthocyanin.title: Anthocyanin

Deciduous.text: Deciduous trees shed their leaves annually as a strategy to conserve water and survive winter. The tree stores nutrients and enters dormancy.
Deciduous.title: Deciduous

responses.text: Clouds are made of tiny water droplets floating in the air.
The sun heats water in oceans, lakes, and puddles, turning it into invisible water vapor.
When this vapor rises and cools, it forms clouds.
Dark clouds have more water drops packed together.
When drops get heavy enough, they fall as rain, and the cycle starts again.

Cloud.text: A cloud is an aerosol consisting of visible masses of tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere.
Cloud.title: Cloud

Evaporation.text: Evaporation is the process by which water changes from a liquid to a gas. The sun provides the energy needed to convert water into water vapor.
Evaporation.title: Evaporation

Condensation.text: Condensation is the process where water vapor becomes liquid. When warm air rises and cools, water vapor condenses around tiny particles to form cloud droplets.
Condensation.title: Condensation

Cumulonimbus_cloud.text: Cumulonimbus clouds are dense, towering clouds that appear dark at their base. They contain large amounts of water and are associated with thunderstorms.
Cumulonimbus_cloud.title: Cumulonimbus cloud

Water_cycle.text: The water cycle describes the continuous movement of water on Earth. Water evaporates, forms clouds, falls as precipitation, and returns to bodies of water.
Water_cycle.title: Water cycle

responses.text: Bees visit flowers and drink sweet nectar with their long tongues.
They carry the nectar back to the hive in a special honey stomach.
At the hive, bees chew the nectar and fan it with their wings to thicken it into honey.
Bees store honey in hexagon-shaped wax cells to eat during winter.
Bees only sting to protect their home - staying calm and moving slowly keeps you safe.

Nectar.text: Nectar is a sugar-rich liquid produced by flowers. Bees collect nectar using their long proboscis and store it in a special stomach for transport.
Nectar.title: Nectar

Honey_stomach.text: The honey stomach, or crop, is a special organ in bees used to store and transport nectar. Enzymes begin converting the nectar during the journey back to the hive.
Honey_stomach.title: Honey stomach

Honey.text: Honey is a sweet substance made by bees from flower nectar. Bees process the nectar by adding enzymes and reducing moisture content through fanning.
Honey.title: Honey

Honeycomb.text: Honeycomb is a structure of hexagonal wax cells built by bees to store honey and pollen. The hexagonal shape is efficient for storage.
Honeycomb.title: Honeycomb

Bee_sting.text: A bee sting is a defensive mechanism. Honey bees typically only sting when they perceive a threat to themselves or their colony.
Bee_sting.title: Bee sting

responses.text: Worms live underground in tunnels they dig through the soil.
When it rains a lot, their tunnels can fill with water.
Worms breathe through their skin and need moisture, but too much water is dangerous.
They come up to the surface to find drier ground and breathe better.
You can gently move them to grass or garden soil where they can dig back down safely.

Earthworm.text: Earthworms are tube-shaped segmented worms that live in soil. They create tunnels by eating through dirt, which helps aerate the soil and improve drainage.
Earthworm.title: Earthworm

Soil_saturation.text: Soil saturation occurs when all soil pores are filled with water. During heavy rain, the water table rises and can flood underground burrows.
Soil_saturation.title: Soil saturation

Cutaneous_respiration.text: Cutaneous respiration is breathing through the skin. Earthworms absorb oxygen directly through their moist skin and cannot breathe if submerged in water.
Cutaneous_respiration.title: Cutaneous respiration

Vermicompost.text: Vermicompost is the product of composting using earthworms. Worms break down organic matter and their castings enrich garden soil.
Vermicompost.title: Vermicompost

responses.text: Hibernation is a deep sleep that helps animals save energy when food is scarce.
Before winter, animals like bears eat lots of food to build up fat.
Their bodies slow way down - heart beats slower, breathing slows, temperature drops.
They use stored fat for energy instead of eating.
In spring, they wake up hungry and ready to find food again!

Hibernation.text: Hibernation is a state of minimal activity and metabolic depression in animals. It allows them to survive periods of cold weather when food is scarce.
Hibernation.title: Hibernation

Hyperphagia.text: Hyperphagia is a period of excessive eating. Before hibernation, animals eat large amounts of food to build up fat reserves for the winter months.
Hyperphagia.title: Hyperphagia

Torpor.text: Torpor is a state of decreased physiological activity. Heart rate, breathing, and body temperature all decrease significantly during hibernation.
Torpor.title: Torpor

Adipose_tissue.text: Adipose tissue, or body fat, stores energy for later use. Hibernating animals rely on their fat reserves for energy throughout the winter.
Adipose_tissue.title: Adipose tissue
